text:
Hi everyone,

I’m working on an article titled: Tools every Instagram creator needs to use in 2022.” 

I would love to talk to Instagram content creators, influencers, or marketers who have built an audience on Instagram. It would be helpful if you could share your firsthand experience with your favorite IG tools that you use to create, promote, and monetize your content. 

Would be happy to link back to your IG page :)

elements.text:

text:
I am running a personal bookstagram account (<http://instagram.com/bookaapi|instagram.com/bookaapi>). No monetisation, small account, but still get too many book reading requests.
My favourite Instragam app is InFrame (<https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.snaperfect.inframe1&hl=en_IN&gl=US>). Can't live without it. If you see my Instagram feed, you can see I only post rectangle images with black square background, and I achieve this with InFrame. I use it to create post to have the uniform Instagram feed.

attachments.fallback: InFrame - Photo Editor & Pics Frame – Apps on Google Play
attachments.text: No crop photo editor with pic frame, blur border, image filter, effects and text
attachments.title: InFrame - Photo Editor & Pics Frame – Apps on Google Play

text:
Hey all! I'm curious to hear if anyone has some experience in handling clients' social media? and how you deal with writing engaging social media messages. Do you have someone that just does that? Or does it fall on the writer of the article?

I'm also wondering if there's anyone to help me with a job ad for a position that could well be a mix of the above and an internal community manager? I've got an idea of what we need but this will be a brand new role for the agency and I'm not sure whether both parts can be covered by the same person, if it's 2 separate roles, if the skills I'm looking for are maybe not for these roles at all??

text: Can anybody recommend great B2B content writers who regularly work with startups in the marketing space? thanks a lot!

elements.text: Can anybody recommend great B2B content writers who regularly work with startups in the marketing space? thanks a lot!

text:
I've seen it done both ways. Pros and cons to each. Volume is a big factor, as well as how the channels are run by the client.

For a smaller client with less budget, comboing the content dev into one person works well. Having the article writer do the social and help with any other form of content is good because the OG author hopefully understands their own hooks and whatnot.

But that person can get overwhelmed if the volume is too intense. Corners might start to get cut, less love could go into social posts, etc. Having a fresh set of eyes to write social can also be good, as the new person might see a new angle or interpretation, might be able to inject more excitement and intrigue since they're not so 'close' to the writing.

This gets expensive though... so you need a client with budget and volume to match.

elements.text:
I've seen it done both ways. Pros and cons to each. Volume is a big factor, as well as how the channels are run by the client.

For a smaller client with less budget, comboing the content dev into one person works well. Having the article writer do the social and help with any other form of content is good because the OG author hopefully understands their own hooks and whatnot.

But that person can get overwhelmed if the volume is too intense. Corners might start to get cut, less love could go into social posts, etc. Having a fresh set of eyes to write social can also be good, as the new person might see a new angle or interpretation, might be able to inject more excitement and intrigue since they're not so 'close' to the writing.

This gets expensive though... so you need a client with budget and volume to match.

text:
As for channel mgmt: if the client has a separate team for social vs other content, it can be a pain to subject a single writer to different processes and people. Rarely do such siloes work in perfect harmony.

usually if a client has these silos, they're big, with volume, and hopefully budget too :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I'm thinking to create a brand new role within the agency for comms manager for our internal comminuities and also clients socials

elements.text: I'm thinking to create a brand new role within the agency for comms manager for our internal comminuities and also clients socials

text:
That could work! Designing new roles are tough.
I assume you've mathed out volume of work to make a new hire viable.

I'd also consider what processes this person will be plugged into. If every client has a different way of doing their socials... then perhaps this new content person would only be dealing with kicking first drafts up the chain. AM/PMs and original writers deal with any client nuances and feedback.

Seeing as they'll be plugged into communities as well—those by nature tend to have myriad of cultures and processes. So this person will need to wear many hats and shift their approach as they switch between communities. That's a lot of mental energy on top of navigating a pile of social content for a variety of clients.

Not to say one person can't handle it, but whatever process design you can manage to help them would be worth considering. Also for hiring a fit, you'd probably want to stay away from folks who like to operate 'deep and narrow' and find those tendencies to play 'shallow and wide.'  #agencylife tends to attract and cultivate the latter, so hopefully that will play to your advantage

So this person will need to wear many hats and shift their approach as they switch between communities. That's a lot of mental energy on top of navigating a pile of social content for a variety of clients.

Not to say one person can't handle it, but whatever process design you can manage to help them would be worth considering. Also for hiring a fit, you'd probably want to stay away from folks who like to operate 'deep and narrow' and find those tendencies to play 'shallow and wide.'  #agencylife tends to attract and cultivate the latter, so hopefully that will play to your advantage

text: We are B2B SaaS. We do a few kinds of webinars -- most are roundtables of experts discussing timely or complex topics, some are a fireside chat with a customer discussing a particular use case for our product. All leave time for audience Q&A or work audience questions in throughout. We're looking into running some customer panels + more BOFU webinars (closer to a product demo) as well. We've got good registration + attendance rates, most viewers are people already in our pipeline (or existing customers) looking for more info on a particular topic.

text: Has anyone here had a really good experience with sponsoring industry newsletters? If so, I'm curious about what type of page you directed the traffic to? A landing page or content? Gated or ungated? Where did you push readers from there and was it a success?

text:
Hi everyone! I’ve been in content marketing for 7 years, first starting out as a freelance copywriter and now running a SEO + content agency with a small team of 4. Lots of ups and downs, both failures and successes, and even today I still struggle a bit… but even through these struggles, I always learn something new everyday.

Anyway, I wanted to share some of my lessons learned by being in the trenches, some of them were tough pills for me to swallow personally. (I might be preaching to the choir here, though!)

1. No one cares about your personal story, only about how you can help THEM.
2. Content and SEO are inseparable.
3. You don’t need Shakespeare writing skills to create good content.
4. If you feel like you’re giving too much away, give even more.
5. The best content does nothing unless you get eyes on them. The more, the better.
6. Content without strategy is fluff.
7. Content with strategy is :fire: (as long as the strategy is good!)
8. For any piece of content, the first 3 lines and the last 3 lines are the most important.
9. Calls to action are diesel fuel for content. Without a CTA, content just sits there.
10. Great content answers people’s questions quickly and completely.
11. Content comes in dozens of types and formats. Pick three and stick with those.
12. Consistency is as important as content quality.

text:
We run a bimonthly newsletter at the company I work in. The newsletter promotes discounts and partner deals. But the prime focus is on promoting our blog posts.

We usually pick about three posts that share tips around a common theme, say Content + Sales, or Content + Social Media.

The blog posts direct readers to the landing page and product.

It is still in its early days, but the newsletter has nearly 50K subscribers so far... So can't really say if it's a success but it must be getting us somewhere.
